title: Textron Stock Just Got Downgraded. It’s Another Sign of Worry About the Economy.
text:
Text size

Investors should avoid Textron shares, according to Vertical Research Partners aerospace and defense analyst Rob Stallard. It’s yet another sign of concern about the state of the economy.



On Friday, Stallard downgraded shares of the industrial conglomerate from Buy to Hold, trimming his target for the stock price to $54, less than 10% above recent levels. Stallard described the move as “taking risk off the table.”

Textron (ticker: TXT) shares have struggled for a while. The stock is up 9% year to date, worse than the 17% gain of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Over the past year, Textron shares are down almost 30%, while the Dow has risen 3%.

Weakening industrial end markets have weighed on the stock. Growth in global industrial production peaked in late 2017 and has decelerated for the past 20 months. U.S. industrial activity contracted for the first time in more than three years in August. About two-thirds of Textron sales is tied to aerospace and defense—a better-performing end market—but Textron has also experienced sales declines in its helicopter and private-jet businesses in recent quarters.

“Small bizjet historically sensitive to the economy,” Stallard wrote. “While the newly certified Longitude should be ramping up through 2020, the rest of the portfolio could be vulnerable to easing demand.” Textron’s newest jet, the Longitude, is ready to sell, but that might not be enough to overcome the damage from a weaker economy, according to the analyst.

The good news for contrarian investors is the stock is cheap, relatively speaking. Textron shares trade for less than 13 times estimated 2020 earnings, a discount to other stocks in the Dow and other industrial components of the S&P 500. Those shares trade for between 15 and 16 times estimated earnings for next year, on average.

Part of the reason Textron gets a lower valuation from investors is its exposure to the car industry. Many auto makers and parts companies trade for less than 10 times estimated earnings. Investors worry that falling global demand for light vehicles will crimp profits.

Like investors, Textron isn’t in love with the automotive business. It announced plans to dispose of its Kautex division in August.

“Textron has sensibly, if belatedly, decided to review its ownership of Kautex, which produces automotive equipment,” wrote Stallard. “While a sale of this business is likely to be around 9% dilutive to 2020 free cash flow per share and earnings per share, it does reduce exposure to the challenging auto market.”

A Kautex sale will reduce Textron earnings. And any business Textron could buy with the cash received, including its own shares, wouldn’t make up the earnings gap. That’s a good definition of “dilutive.” The fact that selling Kautex could be a positive for investor sentiment says a lot about how Wall Street feels about the automotive sector lately.

Write to Al Root at allen.root@dowjones.com
description: Vertical Research Partners suggest investors step to the sidelines and avoid shares of the industrial conglomerate.
